body:
from discussion in the regular meeting: the above design does not allow lags in `y` and `X`, as discussed in #1577.

So we need to extend `LaggedReducer`, replace it by

```python
forecaster = LaggedReducer(
    regressor = RandomForestRegressor(), 
    transformers_X = [
        feature_extractor,
        calendar_features
        ],
    transformers_y = [
        feature_extractor,
    ]
)
```

issue.title: [ENH] window summary transformer

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We've agreed that we need to implement the following transformer:

`WindowSummaryTransformer`

parameters:
* `window_type: "sliding" (default) or "expanding"`
* `window_size: int or datetime.timedelta`
* `agg_func: str or function; if str, one of "mean", "max", "min", "median"; if function, must be pd.DataFrame (n rows) -> pd.DataFrame (one row)`
* `lags: list of int`, list of lags that are used.

`fit` is empty.
In `transform(X)`, computes `agg_func` of each window (ending at any index in `X`) and appends the results to a `pd.DataFrame`. The index of the `agg_func` output is identical with the index at which the window ends.


Might also be worthwhile to have a `LagTransformer`, which has only the `lags` parameter?

body:
I just noticed sth: if `X` is by default used, then `transformers_X` is not needed - we can just use the `ForecastingPipeline`.
I.e., we could have lags in `X` via sth like

```python
forecaster = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[
        ("X_lags", my_lagged_window_summarizer),
        ("lagged_reducer", LaggedReducer(
            regressor = RandomForestRegressor(),
            transformers = [
                feature_extractor,
                calendar_features,
                ],
        )
   ]
)
```

so the transformers in the `LaggedReducer` behave as "featureizers".
This solves the "empty input" issue in the calendar features, since the input is `y`.

The "lags in `X`" are applied in the `ForecastingPipeline`, by `my_lagged_window_summarizer`.

issue.title: [ENH] using window summary features in reduction strategies (with scikit-learn regressors)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would to forecast time series data using scikit learn regressors with moving average smoothing. Currently, sktime module supports lagged time series component (window_length) which is specified in make_reduction method. It would be of great value, if this method supports moving average smoothing (backward rolling window) for target time series. 


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Alternative solution is to use ARIMA, because it supports both Auto Regressive component (lags) and Moving Average component (Smoothing). But it is not as good as GBT algorithm.

**Additional context**
I understand that tsfresh provides tools to extract features but this process takes a lot more time to compute the features.

body:
@fkiraly I suppose you plan to implement direct strategy instead of recursive since it is inefficient. Is there any way to provide window_length (lags) in the ForecastingPipeline?

I can use my_lagged_window_summarizer to get statistics of lagged variables, but what if I want to use lagged variables itself as exogenous variable.

> I can use my_lagged_window_summarizer to get statistics of lagged variables, but what if I want to use lagged variables itself as exogenous variable.

you would define

```python
my_lagged_summarizer = LaggedWindowSummarizer(
  window_functions = {
    etc
     },
)
```

This would ensure that the lagged variables are used in the `LaggedReducer` as exogeneous variables.
The `ForecastingPipeline` applies transformations in `steps` to the exogeneous variables `X`, so once it reaches the `LaggedReducer`, the exogeneous data contains the lagged variables.

@Dwarak-PCI, for your other questions:

> @fkiraly I suppose you plan to implement direct strategy instead of recursive since it is inefficient.

Yes/no - we first focus on direct, but ultimately we also want to implement recursive since it's a common strategy. It is probably not great, but it's the user who should choose in the end...

> Is there any way to provide `window_length` (lags) in the `ForecastingPipeline`?

Partially answered above - the pipeline has no lags, you have to provide it in the transformer component which does the lagging, see examples above.

> @fkiraly I suppose you plan to implement direct strategy instead of recursive since it is inefficient. 

@Dwarak-PCI - Since we already store the training sets of X & y as  forcaster._X and forecaster._y after fit, it will be easy to implement this in the predict method for the recursive strategy. Yes, predict will take longer, but it's feasible.
Thank you very much for the clarification @fkiraly , @ltsaprounis ! Appreciate your time and hard work on this :)

issue.title: [ENH] design `make_reduction` to include window summaries, specify end state

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
@danbartl has created reducers which can make use of window summaries (see issue #1612).

He suggested that this should be one of the default options in `make_reduction`.

We need to see the different options here, and end state signature, this issue is for reaching consensus on that.

In all cases, `make_reduction` should remain downwards compatible (or a case for major API change and deprecation needs to be made).
